ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The CalARP Program developed for this facility is designed to prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating and implementing our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in design, construction, start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the CalARP Program regulation and the OSHA PSM Standard.  This comprehensive program has been developed to enable all those who may be affected to be able to identify and understand the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration process.



Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the regulation.  This Program document, as well as the other documents and reports that are created pursuant to this Program, are made accessible to our employees and to other affected persons in accordance with applicable requirements and the provisions of the CalARP Program.  See Policy Statement for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, which has been posted at the facility.



Emergency response measures have been developed and implemented for proper and safe evacuation and notifications to outside emergency responders.  These measures reflect the established policies of this facility for ensuring the health and safety of all employees and those who may be on site or in the area in the event of an accidental release of ammonia.



This CalARP Program is regularly reviewed and updated as required, and whenever necessary to reflect new or modified tasks and procedures.  Saputo Cheese USA personnel ensure that safety and environmental policies are implemented at this facility by conducting periodic compliance inspections.



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The only regulated substance at this facility subject to the Accidental Release Prevention programs or

the Process Safety Management Standards is anhydrous ammonia in the refrigeration system.



Facility Description



Saputo Cheese USA, Inc. processes milk into packaged provolone and mozzarella cheese for the wholesale and retail markets.  The company operates multiple plants throughout the United States and Canada and the corporate office is located in Lincolnshire, Illinois.



The plant is located at 691 Inyo Street in Newman, California, approximately two blocks east of State Highway 33.  The facility is also located about 1-?o blocks east of the California Northern railroad tracks than run along the east side of State Highway 33.



The area is zoned for industrial use and the area around the facility is comprised of industrial facilities, commercial establishments, and residential neighborhoods.



The facility maintains approximately 115 full time employees on site.  The plant operates seven (7) days per week, 24 hours per day.  



The plant is comprised of a Main Office and Lab building, packaging and processing rooms, Loading Dock, Milk Receiving areas, Whey Building, Cold Rooms, Dry Storage, Boiler Area, Ammonia Refrigeration Compressor Area, Milk Silos and Crystallizing Tanks, Maintenance Office, Parking Lot, and a Guard Shack.  The facility is fenced along the entire perimeter with a main entrance on the south side for employees and visitors.  The truck entrance is located at the west side of the facility.



The Emergency Evacuation Assembly Areas for toxic releases are located at the Parking Lot on the south side and the Bone yard on the north side.  



Process Description



The Saputo Cheese USA Newman California facility operates one (1) refrigeration system which uses approximately 14,600 lbs. anhydrous ammonia as the heat transfer fluid.   The refrigeration system is used for cooling cold storage space, water, glycol, brine, milk tanks, and crystallizing tanks.  The refrigeration system began operation in 1985 and was designed and constructed

under the applicable fire and mechanical codes in effect at the time.



The system is a single-stage, mechanical refrigeration system.  The system utilizes recirculated liquid feed to the cold room evaporator coils, direct (thermal) expansion in the air dehumidifier, and flooded configurations for the chillers, milk and crystallizing tanks.  Cold storage room design temperatures are 32!?F with a design coil temperature of 20!?F (33.5 psig).



The Compressor Area is not enclosed, but is covered by a roof canopy.  The High Pressure Receiver (HPR) is located in an open area enclosed on three sides near the Compressor Area.  System components are connected with steel piping approved for ammonia refrigeration service and the system is controlled by the programmable logic controller (PLC), the microprocessors at the screw compressors, safety switches, detection, and control valves.



The compressors, pressure vessels, pumps, PLC, high-pressure receiver, and purger are located in the Compressor Area; the condensers are located on the Compressor Area roof; the Ammonia Diffusion Tank is located outside the northeast corner of the Dry Storage building; the evaporator coils are located in their respective cold rooms; the Milk Tanks are located east of the Processing Room; and, the Crystallizing Tanks are located north of the Whey Building.

System Operation



The Evaporative Condensers drain high pressure liquid (HPL) to the High Pressure Receiver (HPR), which then supplies liquid to the Recirculator Package (RP1) for recirculated liquid cooling (HTRL) to the evaporator coils in the cold rooms.  Prior to entering the evaporator coils, the ammonia expands and flashes to saturation temperature as the pressure is reduced through the respective expansion valves.  The resulting low-pressure liquid ammonia absorbs heat from the space as the liquid ammonia evaporates in the coils.



The HPR also provides high pressure liquid ammonia to the chiller plate and frame heat exchanger surge drums, the milk and crystallizing tanks surge drums, and the air dehumidifier in the Whey Building.  Liquid injection cooling (LIC) is also provided by the HPR for screw compressor oil cooling.



High temperature saturated ammonia vapor (HTRS) is returned from the cold room evaporator coils and the brine and glycol chillers to the Recirculator Package vessel.  Medium temperature suction (MTS) returns saturated ammonia vapor from the air handling units, milk and crystallizing tanks, and the air dehumidifier to the Suction Accumulator (SA1), where the vapor is separated from the liquid.



As liquid ammonia accumulates in the Suction Accumulator, the liquid is transferred to the Recirculator Package (RP1) via the HTRS line and a pressure differential.  Ammonia vapor (MTS) is provided to the high temperature reciprocating compressors from the Suction Accumulator (SA1) and to the medium temperature screw compressors from the Recirculator Package (RP1).  If configured as a swing compressor, RC5 is provided suction vapor for compression from the Suction Accumulator or the Recirculator Package, depending on the operation configuration.  Currently, the system is configured and operated as a single stage system.



Excess accumulation of liquid ammonia in the Recirculator Package (R

P1) is pumped to the Liquid Transfer Unit (LTU).  Once the LTU liquid level rises to a setpoint, a level sensor opens the three-way solenoid valve, allowing hot gas from the high side discharge of the compressors to drain the liquid in the LTU to the High Pressure Receiver (HPR).   As the liquid level in the LTU drops, the three-way valve changes position and transfers ammonia vapor through the MTS line back to the Recirculator Package.



High-pressure, high-temperature ammonia vapor discharge from the compressors provides hot gas defrost for the evaporator coils, brine chillers, and operation of the automatic liquid transfer system.  The heat of compression in the compressor discharge is removed in the Evaporative Condensers.  An equalizer line between the condenser discharge and the High Pressure Receiver ensures that equal pressure is maintained between the two points to ensure proper liquid draining.



An Autopurger periodically removes noncondensibles from the system.  The Ammonia Diffusion Tank is maintained full of water to absorb a system overpressure release from the vessel pressure relief valves.  Emergency E-stop switches are located at the perimeter of the Compressor Area for emergency shutdown.  Ammonia sensors in the Compressor Area, HPR Area, and production areas trigger audible/visual notifications.



The operation staff consists of the Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Operator/Mechanics.  Staff is responsible for the operation and some of the maintenance of the refrigeration system, as well as the daily monitoring.  Most service and repair activities are contracted to a qualified refrigeration contractor.  



Safety systems include:



!a    Dual pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels;

!a    Ammonia diffusion tank (all relief valve discharge lines lead to the diffusion tank for mixing with water in the event of a release from a component relief valve);

!a    Compressor safety cutouts and control panels to shut down the compressor operation

if safe operating conditions are exceeded;

!a    Liquid level float switches and level columns;

!a    High level vessel alarms;

!a    Emergency shutdown switches (E-Stop);

!a    Ammonia detection and alarm system for response to elevated levels of ammonia vapor.  Detection will trigger audible/visual alarms at pre-set levels;

!a    Spring-loaded, self-closing oil drain valves;

!a    Manual stop valves;

!a    Manual and solenoid-controlled "King Valve" to stop liquid refrigerant flow from the high-pressure receiver;

!a    Physical barriers to protect equipment/piping from collisions (e.g. bollards);

!a    Fire extinguishers; and

!a    Emergency showers and eyewash stations



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The release prevention steps listed in the CalARP Program manual (Chapter 7 (Release Prevention Program)) include the critical elements for preventing accidental releases.  The implementation procedures for each step of release prevention are described in detail in the release prevention chapters (Chapter 8 through Chapter 21).  These steps include all elements as required by the OSHA PSM Standard and the Program 3 requirements of the CalARP regulation.  Specifically, the elements of the release prevention program are:



1.    Employee Participation Program

2.    Process Safety Information

3.    Process Hazard Analysis

4.    Operating Procedures

5.    Training

6.    Contractors

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review

8.    Mechanical Integrity

9.    Hot Work

10.    Management of Change

11.    Incident Investigation

12.    Emergency Planning & Response

13.    Compliance Audit

14.    Trade Secrets



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There has been one accidental release of ammonia at this Saputo Cheese USA facility in the past five years that is subject to the CalARP or EPA Accidental Release Prevention Program five-year accident history reporting requirements.  The release caused one minor injury and occurred March 31, 2011.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Saput

o Cheese USA maintains an Emergency Planning & Response Program as described in the CalARP Program manual and the Emergency Action Plan.  As a facility that will not respond to uncontrolled releases, the emergency response measures primarily include the safe evacuation of all personnel and notification to outside emergency responders.  Incidental releases that do not pose an imminent safety hazard may be abated by employees or contractors who are trained to provide such a response, are wearing the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), are authorized by Saputo Cheese USA to perform such activities, and are in the area of the release at the time of discovery.
